required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Exploration of Investigating ICU Mobilisation With Vasoactive Drugs
clinical_study.official_title: Investigating the Safety of Mobilising Intensive Care Unit Patients Receiving Vasoactive Drugs: An Exploratory Observational Study

brief_summary.textblock:
There is a need to know more about the safety of mobilizing intensive care unit (ICU) patients who are receiving vasoactive drugs that support the heart and blood pressure. But before this research can be done, several uncertainties need to be addressed.
To answer these uncertainties, the investigators will ask ICU patients receiving vasoactive drugs to take part in a study in three main stages. Firstly ICU patients will be asked whether they would be happy to take part in a future research trial on the safety of mobilizing patients who are receiving vasoactive drugs. Secondly, data will be collected about the current mobilization on vasoactive drugs that occurs. Finally, the investigators will try to follow up these patients 60 days after they start the study, to carry out some questionnaires and a walking test with the patients. These tests may be used in future research to measure the effect of mobilizing patients on vasoactive drugs.

detailed_description.textblock:
The current evidence is insufficient to accurately guide clinicians to know when it is safe to start mobilizing intensive care unit (ICU) patients receiving vasoactive drugs. Before a randomized controlled trial can be designed, several uncertainties need to be addressed. This includes clarifying what standard care is, what potential recruitment rates would be and what the most suitable primary outcome measure is.
This study is an exploratory observational study which will aim to recruit up to 40 ICU patients receiving vasoactive drugs to further clarify standard care and to measure preliminary feasibility outcomes.
Upon enrolment, patients and clinicians will be surveyed about the hypothetical acceptability of recruitment into a future randomized controlled trial. Then any routine mobilization that occurs whilst the patient is receiving vasoactive drugs will be analyzed, for example, to describe how clinicians assessed safety for mobilization. Finally, patient participants will be followed up at day 60 to assess the feasibility of measuring candidate primary outcome measures.

primary_outcome.measure: Hypothetical Recruitment Rate for a Future Randomised Controlled Trial.
primary_outcome.description: The number of patient participants who would hypothetically accept being randomised into a future trial on the safety of mobilising patients receiving vasoactive drugs.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Follow-up at 60 Days
primary_outcome.description: Patient participant follow-up rate at 60 days.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Rating the 'Early Versus no Rehabilitation' Randomisation Scenario Was Acceptable
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (approximately one day from enrolment)
secondary_outcome.description: Survey measuring participant acceptance of hypothetical randomisation scenarios: scenario 1: early versus no rehabilitation

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Rating the 'Early Rehabilitation Versus Standard Care' Randomization Scenario as Acceptable
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (approximately one day from enrolment)
secondary_outcome.description: Survey measuring participant acceptance of hypothetical randomization scenarios: scenario 2: early rehabilitation versus standard care

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Rating the 'Protocolised Rehabilitation Versus Standard Care' Randomisation Scenario as Acceptable
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (approximately one day from enrolment)
secondary_outcome.description: Survey measuring participant acceptance of hypothetical randomization scenarios: scenario 3: protocolised rehabilitation versus standard care

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Where Participant Pre-morbid Comorbidities Measurement Was Not Completed.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (approximately one day from enrolment)
secondary_outcome.description: Quantity of missing data resulting from measurement of participant pre-morbid co-morbidities.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Where Participant Pre-morbid Frailty Measurements Were Not Completed.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (approximately one day from enrolment)
secondary_outcome.description: Quantity of missing data resulting from measurement of participant pre-morbid frailty.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Where Participant Pre-morbid Physical Function Measurement Was Not Completed.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (approximately one day from enrolment)
secondary_outcome.description: Quantity of missing data resulting from measurement of participant pre-morbid physical function.

secondary_outcome.measure: Who Made the Final Decision Whether to Mobilize the Patient
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of ICU stay (average of 7 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Recorded whenever a physiotherapist reviews a patient participant for potential physical rehabilitation whilst they are receiving vasoactive drugs and the patient was mobilized.

secondary_outcome.measure: The Reasons for the Decision When Patient Was Mobilized.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of ICU stay (average of 7 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Recorded whenever a physiotherapist reviews a patient participant for potential physical rehabilitation whilst they are receiving vasoactive drugs and the patient was mobilized. Qualitative measure: reasons underwent content analysis, with the outcome being the themes summarizing the reasons.

secondary_outcome.measure: Who Made the Final Decision Whether to Not Mobilize the Patient
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of intensive care stay (average 7 days)
secondary_outcome.description: Recorded whenever a physiotherapist reviews a patient for potential physical rehabilitation whilst they are receiving vasoactive drugs and the patient was not mobilized.

secondary_outcome.measure: The Reasons for the Decision When the Patient Was Not Mobilized.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of intensive care stay (average 7 days)
secondary_outcome.description: Recorded whenever a physiotherapist reviews a patient for potential physical rehabilitation whilst they are receiving vasoactive drugs and the patient was not mobilized. Qualitative variable: reasons underwent qualitative analysis, with the output of a list of themes summarizing the reasons.

secondary_outcome.measure: The Reason Why a Mobilisation Treatment Was Stopped
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of ICU stay (average of 7 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Recorded if a mobilisation treatment on vasoactive drugs is routinely carried out.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Serious Adverse Events
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through whole of study, an estimated 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: Number of serious adverse events

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of ICU Physical Rehabilitation Adverse Events
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of ICU stay (average of 7 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Recorded using ICU physical rehabilitation adverse event tool, both by treating clinician and by researcher case note review.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time Taken to Complete an ICU Physical Rehabilitation Adverse Event Tool.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of ICU stay (average of 7 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Adverse event tool is completed if a mobilisation treatment on vasoactive drugs is routinely carried out.

secondary_outcome.measure: Loss of Information That Occurs When Completing ICU Physical Rehabilitation Adverse Event Tool.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of ICU stay (average of 7 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Tool completed both by treating clinician and by researcher case note review. Number of mobilization treatment sessions on vasoactive drugs where adverse event tool is complete.

secondary_outcome.measure: Feasibility and Usability of an ICU Physical Rehabilitation Adverse Event Tool Measured by Survey.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through second half of the study, an estimated 3 months
secondary_outcome.description: A survey measuring user opinion on whether an adverse event tool was for example understandable and an appropriate length using a scale with 'yes', 'no' or 'unsure' responses. Survey adapted from Hodgson, C., Needham, D., Haines, K., Bailey, M., Ward, A., Harrold, M., Young, P., Zanni, J., Buhr, H., Higgins, A., Presneill, J. & Berney, S. 2014. Feasibility and inter-rater reliability of the ICU mobility scale. Heart Lung, 43.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Mobilisation Treatment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of hospital stay (average of 22 days)
secondary_outcome.description: Number of days to first rehabilitation treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Being Able to Sit Out of Bed.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of hospital stay (average of 22 days)
secondary_outcome.description: Regardless of the assistance required.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Being Able to Stand.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of hospital stay (average of 22 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Regardless of the assistance required.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Being Able to Walk.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through duration of hospital stay (average of 22 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Regardless of assistance required.

secondary_outcome.measure: Intensive Care Unit Length of Stay.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to ICU discharge (an average of 7 days)

secondary_outcome.measure: Hospital Length of Stay
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to hospital discharge (average of 22 days)

secondary_outcome.measure: Intensive Care Unit Mobility Scale Level at ICU Discharge.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: ICU discharge (an average of 7 days from ICU admission)
secondary_outcome.description: Intensive care unit mobility scale records a patient's mobility level from 0 to 10, where 0 means no mobility and 10 means walking without assistance from people or a physical aid.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patient Participants Where All Candidate Primary Outcomes Are Completed.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 60 days.
secondary_outcome.description: Candidate primary outcomes: mortality, health-related quality of life, disability, physical functioning questionnaire and walking test.

secondary_outcome.measure: The Number of Patient Participants Who Completed Each Individual Candidate Primary Outcome.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 60 days.
secondary_outcome.description: Candidate primary outcomes: mortality, health-related quality of life, disability, physical functioning questionnaire and walking test.

secondary_outcome.measure: Data to Inform a Future Sample Size for a Future Randomized Controlled Trial.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 60 days.
secondary_outcome.description: Measures of central tendency and variability of data for candidate outcome measures to inform a sample size for future randomised controlled trial, e.g. physical functioning measured by the physical function domain of the RAND 36-Item Health Survey 1.0 Questionnaire (RAND SF-36 v1), scores range from 0-100, where a higher score means better physical functioning.

arm_group.description: Adult intensive care patients receiving vasoactive drugs
Clinicians for participation in a survey on the hypothetical randomization of patient participants in a future randomized controlled trial.
Clinicians for participation in a survey on the feasibility of an ICU physical rehabilitation adverse event tool.

study_pop.textblock: Intensive care unit patients and clinicians.

criteria.textblock:
Patient participants:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients admitted to the ICU who are receiving vasoactive drugs.
- Age greater than or equal to 18 years old.
- Expected to remain admitted to the ICU for at least 24 hours post-enrolment.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any patient who is expected to die imminently, as per clinical opinion.
- Any patient where mobilization is contraindicated by the nature of their existing injuries.
- Where it is clear from the medical records that participants are prisoners or offenders on probation.
- Patients with neuromuscular disease or acute brain injury or spinal cord injury.
- If the patient and/or their consultee is unable to speak English.
Clinicians participating in a survey on hypothetical randomization of patient participants:
Inclusion criteria:
- Clinicians who work in the intensive care unit where a patient participant has been admitted.
Exclusion criteria:
- None.
Clinician participants in the survey on the feasibility of the ICU physical rehabilitation adverse event tool:
Inclusion criteria:
- An ICU clinician at the research site.
- Has used the ICU physical rehabilitation adverse event tool as part of this research study.
Exclusion criteria:
- None.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

measure.title: Age
measure.description: Not recorded for intensive care clinicians or intensive care rehabilitation clinicians.
measure.population: Data only collected for Intensive care patients arm for this baseline measure.

measure.description: Not recorded for intensive care clinicians or intensive care rehabilitation clinicians.
measure.population: Data only collected for Intensive care patients arm for this baseline measure.

BMI
measure.description: Not recorded for intensive care clinicians or intensive care rehabilitation clinicians.
measure.population: Number analysed in row differs from overall due to missing data. Data only collected for Intensive care patients arm for this baseline measure.

measure.title: APACHE (Acute physiology and chronic health evaluation)II score
measure.description: A severity of disease classification system. A scale of 0 to 71, with a higher score equating to more severe disease and mortality risk. Not recorded for intensive care clinicians or intensive care rehabilitation clinicians.
measure.population: Data only collected for Intensive care patients arm for this baseline measure.

measure.title: Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score
measure.description: A score that measures the amount of organ failure. Range 0-24, increasing score = worse organ failure.
measure.population: Data only collected for Intensive care patients arm for this baseline measure.

measure.title: Duration of invasive mechanical ventilation
measure.description: Only recorded for intensive care patients arm.
measure.population: Baseline measure only recorded for intensive care patients arm.

measure.title: Profession
measure.description: Profession of clinician participant. Not recorded for intensive care unit patients.
measure.population: Data not collected for Intensive care patients arm for this baseline measure.

measure.title: ICU experience
measure.description: Amount of intensive care unit experience in years. Not recorded for intensive care unit patients.
measure.population: Missing data for two participants. Data not collected for Intensive care patients arm for this baseline measure. Data was collected for intensive care rehabilitation clinicians, however this has been summarized with a different measure type and dispersion, therefore is reported as a separate variable.

measure.title: ICU experience of rehabilitation clinicians
measure.population: Missing data for one participant. Data not collected for Intensive care patients arm for this baseline measure. Data was collected for intensive care clinicians arms, but summarised as a different measure type and dispersion, therefore reported as a different baseline measure.

measure.title: Healthcare experience
measure.description: Not recorded for intensive care unit patients.
measure.population: Missing data for two participants. Data not collected for Intensive care patients arm for this baseline measure. Data was collected for intensive care rehabilitation clinicians, however this was summarized as a different measure type and dispersion, therefore this is displayed as a separate variable.

measure.title: Healthcare experience of rehabilitation clinicians
measure.population: Missing data for one participant. Data not collected for Intensive care patients arm for this baseline measure. Data was collected for intensive care clinicians, however this was summarized as a different measure type and dispersion, therefore this is represented as a different baseline measure.

outcome.title: Who Made the Final Decision Whether to Mobilize the Patient
outcome.description: Recorded whenever a physiotherapist reviews a patient participant for potential physical rehabilitation whilst they are receiving vasoactive drugs and the patient was mobilized.
outcome.time_frame: Through duration of ICU stay (average of 7 days).
outcome.population: Number of mobilization treatments where data was available for analysis. Please note the categories presented below are not mutually exclusive e.g. a decision whether to mobilize could have been made with a nurse and a doctor. Therefore, the sum of the categories will be greater than the overall number of participants analyzed.

class.title: Vasoactive dose decreasing and blood pressure improved

Surgical wound safe to mobilise / medically stable

outcome.title: Feasibility and Usability of an ICU Physical Rehabilitation Adverse Event Tool Measured by Survey.
outcome.description: A survey measuring user opinion on whether an adverse event tool was for example understandable and an appropriate length using a scale with 'yes', 'no' or 'unsure' responses. Survey adapted from Hodgson, C., Needham, D., Haines, K., Bailey, M., Ward, A., Harrold, M., Young, P., Zanni, J., Buhr, H., Higgins, A., Presneill, J. & Berney, S. 2014. Feasibility and inter-rater reliability of the ICU mobility scale. Heart Lung, 43.
outcome.time_frame: Through second half of the study, an estimated 3 months
outcome.population: Number of clinicians who completed the survey

group.title: ICU Rehabilitation Clinicians
group.description: Clinicians for participation in a survey on the feasibility of an ICU physical rehabilitation adverse event tool.

measure.title: Feasibility and Usability of an ICU Physical Rehabilitation Adverse Event Tool Measured by Survey.
measure.description: A survey measuring user opinion on whether an adverse event tool was for example understandable and an appropriate length using a scale with 'yes', 'no' or 'unsure' responses. Survey adapted from Hodgson, C., Needham, D., Haines, K., Bailey, M., Ward, A., Harrold, M., Young, P., Zanni, J., Buhr, H., Higgins, A., Presneill, J. & Berney, S. 2014. Feasibility and inter-rater reliability of the ICU mobility scale. Heart Lung, 43.
measure.population: Number of clinicians who completed the survey

class.title: Will people filling out the tool know how to?
Are the adverse events adequately defined?
Are the adverse events irrelevant or misleading?
Are the adverse events offensive or inappropriate?
Are adverse events unnecessary or repetitive?
Is the tool an appropriate length?

outcome.title: Time to First Mobilisation Treatment
outcome.description: Number of days to first rehabilitation treatment
outcome.time_frame: Through duration of hospital stay (average of 22 days)
outcome.population: Number of participants with data available for this outcome.

outcome.title: Intensive Care Unit Mobility Scale Level at ICU Discharge.
outcome.description: Intensive care unit mobility scale records a patient's mobility level from 0 to 10, where 0 means no mobility and 10 means walking without assistance from people or a physical aid.
outcome.time_frame: ICU discharge (an average of 7 days from ICU admission)
outcome.population: Number of participants with data available.

group.title: Intensive Care Patients
group.description: Adult intensive care patients receiving vasoactive drugs Mobilization: Physical rehabilitation

measure.title: Intensive Care Unit Mobility Scale Level at ICU Discharge.
measure.description: Intensive care unit mobility scale records a patient's mobility level from 0 to 10, where 0 means no mobility and 10 means walking without assistance from people or a physical aid.
measure.population: Number of participants with data available.

outcome.title: Number of Patient Participants Where All Candidate Primary Outcomes Are Completed.
outcome.description: Candidate primary outcomes: mortality, health-related quality of life, disability, physical functioning questionnaire and walking test.

outcome.title: Data to Inform a Future Sample Size for a Future Randomized Controlled Trial.
outcome.description: Measures of central tendency and variability of data for candidate outcome measures to inform a sample size for future randomised controlled trial, e.g. physical functioning measured by the physical function domain of the RAND 36-Item Health Survey 1.0 Questionnaire (RAND SF-36 v1), scores range from 0-100, where a higher score means better physical functioning.
outcome.time_frame: 60 days.
outcome.population: Number of participants with data available

group.title: Intensive Care Patients
group.description: Adult intensive care patients receiving vasoactive drugs Mobilization: Physical rehabilitation

measure.title: Data to Inform a Future Sample Size for a Future Randomized Controlled Trial.
measure.description: Measures of central tendency and variability of data for candidate outcome measures to inform a sample size for future randomised controlled trial, e.g. physical functioning measured by the physical function domain of the RAND 36-Item Health Survey 1.0 Questionnaire (RAND SF-36 v1), scores range from 0-100, where a higher score means better physical functioning.
measure.population: Number of participants with data available

reported_events.time_frame: Intensive care patients: 60 days Intensive care unit clinicians: From time of enrolment to timepoint in study where no further questionnaires were required of this study arm (length of time variable as a clinician participant could take part in one or multiple questionnaires depending if they were completing a clinical shift when a patient participant was recruited). ICU rehabilitation clinicians: From time of enrolment to time that questionnaire was returned to researcher.
reported_events.desc: This study was observational (not involving changes to standard care) therefore we only monitored for and report adverse events and serious adverse events that are related to study procedures which involve contact with the participant.

group.title: Intensive Care Patients
group.description: Adult intensive care patients receiving vasoactive drugs Mobilization: Physical rehabilitation

group.description: Clinicians for participation in a survey on the hypothetical randomization of patient participants in a future randomized controlled trial.

group.description: Clinicians for participation in a survey on the feasibility of an ICU physical rehabilitation adverse event tool.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
